awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Spectrally-Encoded Ultrafast Microwave Panoramic Camera
awd_abstract_narration:
Current microwave radar systems using conventional beam scanning techniques cannot simultaneously achieve a panoramic field of view (FOV) and high scanning speed. This is due to intrinsic hardware latencies from mechanical rotors or electronic phase shifters, or excessive computation time from digital signal processing.  These limitations can fundamentally be overcome by transforming imaging concepts from optics into microwaves, enabling a microwave panoramic camera (MPC). The knowledge and understanding of such integration will lead to a novel category of radars and imaging sensors that can be used for a wide range of sensing applications. The proposed MPC will be applied, in particular, to automotive radar to provide driver assistance, making driving safer and more convenient.  The fast sensing speed and panoramic FOV enabled by MPC-based radars will provide early warning of potential collisions to drivers. Furthermore, the ultrafast frame rate of MPCs will allow differentiation of objects by detecting their Doppler signatures.  With a panoramic FOV, MPCs can also be used in autonomous driving systems requiring constant monitoring of road situations.  The educational component of the proposed work will integrate advanced automotive technologies into undergraduate education by engaging community college students in the Metro Detroit area.   It will be conducted through the University Bound Program, a State of Michigan King-Chavez-Parks (KCP) Initiative.  Community college students, especially those from underrepresented groups, will be encouraged to participate in research activities in antenna and microwave engineering essential for today's automotive radar imaging sensors and telematics. 

The objective of this research is to transform spectrally encoded confocal microscopy, a fiber-based optical imaging method for high-speed scanning, into the microwave and millimeter-wave regime. This integration will enable the proposed microwave panoramic camera with ultrafast scanning speed and a panoramic field of view. The technical approach relies on the creation of transmission-line based microwave metamaterials, also known as composite right/left-handed transmission lines. By tailoring microwave metamaterials to form a frequency scanned array, a two-dimensional frequency-to-space mapping mechanism can be realized.  Utilizing the two-dimensional angular mapping scheme along with the range information obtained from the reflected signal will result in an image of the scene in three dimensions.  This research will demonstrate the capability to capture a three-dimensional microwave image with 180-degree FOV in both azimuth and elevation, with a frame-rate speed of 1 MHz.  The fast frame refresh rate will allow any Doppler and micro-Doppler effects of moving objects to be captured and exploited for target recognition and identification. Furthermore, by engineering the dispersion characteristics of microwave metamaterials, the proposed MPC can be designed to work in multiple bands, making it feasible to perform dual-band operations for radar systems, such as 24 GHz and 77 GHz automotive radar sensors.

por.por_cntn:
The overall goal of this research project aims to transform spectrally encoded confocal microscopy in optics into the microwave regime by harnessing the dispersion characteristics of electromagnetic metamaterials (MTMs), thereby enabling a new kind of microwave and mmWave radar sensing scheme with fast scanning speed and a wide field of view. To this end, we have first developed a 2D frequency-space mapping array using transmission-line based microwave MTMs or so-called composite right/left-handed (CRLH) transmission lines to realize both leaky wave antennas (LWAs) and antenna array feed networks, which can perform frequency-space mapping and beamforming over the entire full-hemisphere without the use of phase shifters or mixers. Moreover, we have incorporated the MTM antenna aperture with the inverse scattering method to reconstruct the images with a wide field of view. In particular, we have adopted the linear sampling method (LSM) to conduct remote sensing and microwave tomography by integrating the frequency mapping MTM LWAs.

Leveraging both 1D and 2D frequency-space mapping characteristics of MTM LWAs, various non-contact and non-invasive radar architectures have been designed and developed in both microwave and mmWave regimes. In addition to a K-band homodyne radar transceiver integrated with MTM LWAs, a self-injection-locked (SIL) radar sensor based on MTM LWAs to detect multi-target vital sign and location simultaneously has been developed, in which the distance from the radar sensor to the targets is obtained by imposing the frequency-shift keying (FSK) modulation on the radar waveforms, whereas the vital sign signals of multiple targets can be extracted from the Doppler frequency spectrum. Moreover, a new kind of radar sensor based on a super-regenerative oscillator (SRO) with very high sensitivity has been developed for vital sign detection and motion sensing. By harnessing the intrinsic sensitivity period of the SRO and the frequency-space mapping relationship of MTM LWA, the vital sign signals including respiration rates and heartbeat rates, as well as distance information of multiple targets can be detected using the proposed SRO-based MTM LWA. In addition, when utilized as a near field sensor, the SRO radar can perform non-contact fingertip microwave plethysmography. Furthermore, the concept of pulsed radar is incorporated into the MTM SRO radar to measure the time of flight for obtaining the target distance.

The broader impacts entail both educational and societal aspects. The research project has provided research opportunities for both undergraduate and graduate students, including underrepresented minority groups, to conduct microwave remote sensing and imaging. The resulting MTM-based frequency scanning antenna array in the microwave and mmWave band enables a new sensing scheme that can achieve both wide field of view and high sensing speed over the entire field of view. The integration of LSM with the MTM LWA array, has created a new approach to reconstructing 2D and 3D images via microwave tomography and remote sensing. In addition, the integration of the MTM antenna array and newly developed transceiver structures such as SRO and SIL architectures may also lead to high-performance short-range target detection with reduced system complexity, low cost and low power.  While the technology has potential to be implemented into active automobile safety systems, it can also be applied to surveillance radars, security screening systems, vital sign sensors and microwave tomography with better performances and faster speed to enhance national security and health.
